lines.text: [Stuffy has grabbed some poison to drink]
Hey, don't drink that poison! That's $4.00 an ounce!
Oh, well, uh, to begin with I took four years at Vassar.
Vassar? But that's a girls' college.
I found that out the third year. I'd 've been there yet, but I went out for the swimming team.
[Dr. Hackenbush is pointing to a portrait of one of Judy's parents]
You know, I proposed to your mother once.
But that's my father!
No wonder he turned me down.
[Taking a pulse]
Either he's dead or my watch has stopped.
I want to be near you. I want you to hold me. Oh! Hold me closer! Closer! Closer!
If I hold you any closer, I'll be in back of you!
It's the old, old story. Boy meets girl - Romeo and Juliet - Minneapolis and St. Paul!
Just a minute, Mrs Upjohn. That looks like a horse pill to me.
Oh, you've taken them before.
Are you sure, Doctor, you haven't made a mistake?
You have nothing to worry about. The last patient I gave one of those to won the Kentucky Derby.
May I examine this, please? Do you actually give those to your patients? Isn't it awfully large for a pill?
Well, it was too small for a basketball, and I didn't know what to do with it. Say, you're awfully large for a pill yourself.
[Tony offers Dr. Hackenbush a hint book]
One dollar and you'll remember me all your life.
That's the most nauseating proposition I ever had.
[Hackenbush is asked to 'OK' a file]
I'm too busy right now. I'll tell you what. I'll put the 'O' on now and come back later for the 'K.'
Oh, what is the meaning of this? Oh, why you little pest. Well!
Say, what's the matter with you muggs. Haven't you got any gallantry at all?
She's in with Whitmore. She's trying to frame you.
I wouldn't mind framing her. A prettier picture, I've never seen.
Thank you.
Thank yo.
Hey Doc! Doc, I'm tell you a secret - she's out to get you.
Why, I've never been so insulted in my life.
Well, it's early yet.
Dr. Hackenbush tells me I'm the only case in history. I have high blood pressure on my right side and low blood pressure on my left side.
There is no such thing. She looks as healthy as any woman I ever met.
You don't look as though you've ever met a healthy woman.
Well, that's-a fine. Now we owe the Sheriff a hundred and twenty dollars and a sock.
Hey doc, can you see us?
If I can't there's something wrong with my glasses.
[Talking about Stuffy]
I think he's a ubangi.
Well, I'll get a hammer and "ubangi" that right off.
[Stuffy blows a balloon during a medical exam]
If that's his adam's apple, he's got yellow fever.
He's got in-grown balloons.
Oh doctor. Thank you.
Thank "yu". Do you like gardenias?
I adore them. How did you know?
I didn't, so I got you forget-me-nots. One whiff of this and you'll forget everything.
[Hackenbush hands her a wilted sunflower. He seats her and pushes in her chair at the table]
Thank you.
Thank "yu".

[handing him her wrap]
Do you mind?
Not at all. I always take the wrap.
Are you a man or a mouse?
You put a piece of cheese down there and you'll find out.

[to Dr. Steinberg]
Don't point that beard at me! It might go off!
Emily, I have a confession to make. I really am a horse doctor. But marry me, and I'll never look at another horse.
Have you got a woman in here?
If I haven't, I've wasted 30 minutes of valuable time!
Well, you better get her out of here! This is the last time I'm going to tell you.
The last time? Can I depend on that?
Have you got a woman in here?
If I haven't, I've wasted thirty minutes of valuable time.

[examining Stuffy with an auriscope]
I haven't seen anything like this in years. The last time I saw a head like that was in a bottle of formaldehyde.
Told you he was sick.

[pointing to Stuffy's neck]
That's all pure desecration along there. He's got about a 15% metabolism, with an overactive thyroid and a glandular affectation of about 3%.
That's bad.
With a 1% mentality.
[Stuffy grins]
He's what we designate as the crummy moronic type. All in all, this is the most gruesome looking piece of blubber I've ever peered at.
Hey doc. Hey doc!
Huh?
You gotta the looking glass turned around, you're looking at yourself.
Here's a ten-dollar bill and shoot the change, will you?
I got-a no change. I'll have to give you nine more books.
She's so in love with me, she doesn't know anything. That's why she's in love with me.
[Stuffy is getting an examination]
Say "ah!"
[Stuffy opens his mouth, but says nothing]
Louder!
[Stuffy does the same thing]
Louder!
[Stuffy does the same thing. Dr. Hackenbush starts to leave]
What are you doing?
I'm going to get my ears checked. I'm deaf.
You're not deaf. It's just him.
[referring to Ms. Marlowe]
You've got it all wrong. This is my aunt. She's come to talk over some old family matters.
I wish I had an aunt look like that.
Well, take it up with your uncle.

[who has been instructed by Dr Hackenbush to wave her arms up and down, as part of a physical examination]
How long do you want me to do this, Doctor?
Just until you fly away.
[after taking his watch from under Steinberg's gaze and tossing it in a wash basin]
I'd rather have it rusty than missing.
I haven't seen so much mudslinging since the last election!
Steinberg, what do you do with your old razor blades?

[disgused as an ice cream vendor]
You wanna something hot?
Not now, I just ate. Besides I don't like hot ice cream.
[Tony is selling Hackenbush one book after another at the race track]
Well, justa by accident I think I gotta one right here.
A lotta accidents around here for a quiet neighborhood.
We come to hang the paper.
How about hanging yourselves?
The doctor seems reluctant to discuss his medical experiences.
Well, medically, my experiences have been most unexciting. Except during the flu epidemic.
Ah, and what happened?
I got the flu.

[to Stuffy]
Morgan fired you, huh? He wanted you to throw the race?
Wanted Stuffy to be crooked, eh?
Yeah, you know he's honest!
[Stuffy's hand starts to creep into ice cream cart - Tony slams the lid of his down onto it]
He's honest, but you gotta watch him a little.
Hey, boss! C'mere! Sun-Up is the worst horse on the track!
I notice he wins all the time.
Aw, just because he comes in first.
Well, I don't want 'em any better than first.
Getta your tootsie-frootsie ice cream!
If you'll excuse me, I'll go and bring in the rest of the staff.

[to Whitmore]
Why don't you go out and bring in something. Preferably your resignation.
And do be nice to Mrs. Upjohn, won't you?
Well, she's not exactly my type, but for you I'd make love to a crocodile!
Excuse, please. We're sure getting a lot of new customers since that Doctor Hac-ken-a-pus is coming.
Did you say Hackenbush?
Yes, ma'am.
I wonder if that could be the same one! Where's he come from?
Where's your Hac-ken-a-pus come from?
Palmville, Florida.
That's the one!
Who's Doctor Hackenbush?
I don't know. But if she wants a Hac-ken-a-bush, she's gonna get a Hac-ken-a-pus.
Here, boy. Here, boy, eh, take these bags and run up to my room and, eh, here's a dime for yourself.
Oh, no, no, no, no, no. Eh, this is Mr. Whitmore, our business manager.
Oh, I'm terribly sorry. Here's a quarter.
Surely, you don't question the Doctor's ability.
No, not exactly. But, running a sanitarium calls for a man with peculiar talents.
You don't have to look any further, I've got the most peculiar talents of any doctor you've ever met.
I want to announce your association with the Sanitarium. We'll send your picture to all the papers.
The Florida papers?
Yes. We want it for publicity.
Publicity? Oh, we mustn't have any of that, Miss Standish. You know, the ethics of my profession.
But, we have to get new patients.
Well, after all, the old patients were good enough for your father.

[Speaking on the phone, believes he is talking to the Florida Medical Board, but, it is really Dr. Hackenbush, pretending to be Medical Board Records Department Manager, Colonel Hawkings]
I want to know about Doctor Hackenbush.
[Hackenbush, in an adjacent office, buzzes the dictograph. Whitmore goes to answer it]
Yes?
Whitmore, you'll have to cut out that squawking. The patients are all complaining.
[Talking on the phone in a Southern accent, pretending to be Colonel Hawkings]
And, eh, I hope, sir, that's the information that you require.
I'm sorry, Colonel, I didn't hear it. I was called to the dictograph.

[On the phone, pretending to be Colonel Hawkings]
What was that you said, sir?
I was called to the dictograph!

[Talking to Stuffy]
You're hungry, eh? You want-a some ice cream? You want-a nice big steak? With spinach? Alright, alright, no spinach. No spinach. Apple-a pie? And a-beautiful nurses? Oh, baby, come on you a-gonna get a nurse. Oh my, you gonna get-a plenty to eat.
What's the matter with Mrs. Upjohn?
Nothing, in its most violent form.
Doctor, may I have an OK on this, please?
I'm too busy right now. I"ll tell you what, I'll put the O on now and come back later for the K.
Doctor Hackenbush.
A little later.
[to his nurse]
Eh, get me the Turkish bath.
Yes sir.
Doctor, the Turkish Bath.
[Hands him the phone]
Hello. Yes, will you look in the steam room and see if my frankfurters are done?
How would you like me to dance away from you?
I'd be satisfied if you'd dance off my feet.
Hugo, I'm disappointed in you. To think of you dancing with that strange woman.
Well, don't think of it. Think of me dancing with you.
Oh, eh, how about a little scotch?
Why, I'd love it. Oh, eh, I'll ring for some.
Thank yo.
Thank yo.
[Picks up the phone]
Will you have the bellhop hop up with some hop scotch.
[Hangs up phone]
I'll flip you to see who pays for it.
Oh-oh, Doctor.

[Stuffy walks in wearing a Sherlock Holmes outfit and starts examining Flo's bare shoulder with a magnifying glass]
Oh!
If you're looking for my fingerprints, you're a little early!

[In walk Tony and Stuffy, disguised as Doctors]
Dr. Hackenbush, tell me, who sent for these men?
You don't have to send for them. You just rub a lamp and they appear.
My name is Steinberg.
[Goes to shake Dr. Steinberg's hand]

Dr. Steinberg, by a strange coincidence, this is another Dr. Steinberg. May I take my great friend and introduce my colleagues and good friends, another Dr. Steinberg. This is a Dr. Steinberg, Dr. Steinberg. Dr. Steinberg. And a Mrs. Steinberg. And Doctor, I'd like you to meet another Dr. Steinberg. And, eh, that's a, that's a Steinberg junior.

[to Stuffy]
Take her pulse. Take her pulse!

[Stuffy takes Mrs. Upjohn's purse]
Oh, no-no-no! My purse! My purse! My purse! He has my purse!
You must forgive him, he doesn't spell very well, Mrs. Upjohn.
Ah, signorina, gentile, e bella. Oh, baby, you look-a good to me.
Oh, oh-oh, stop it.
Hey, wait a minute. I thought you came here to see me?
Well, I can see you from here.
Oh, oh, get up, you... oh, oh...
